content.description: Up the left of the crack (right side is off). Starts matched on the pie that sits in the crack, moves out to a ledge, then a throw to the top of the middle segment of the boulder. Once standing on the ledge, the last move is pretty easy.
content.protection: At least one pad, but preferably 2. There are some rocks under the landing, so place your mat to cover them.   You may want another small mat to make the landing from the downclimb less harsh.
content.location: On the broken boulder, on its face toward New Cross Dr. The problem is up the left side of the crack.

content.description: Start pinching the bottom of the pie and the X under the roof. Feet straddle the crack. Bump out to the pinch on the outer ledge (use your thumb to stick it)and a side pull on the right side of the crack. Pull up to the top of the middle segment, work the hands to find positivity, then top out.   Other than the bottom third of the rock, the left side of the crack is off.
content.protection: Pad   Consider a pad for the downclimb.
content.location: On the broken boulder, on its face toward New Cross Dr. The problem is up the right side and the face to the right of the crack.

content.description: Sit start with hand jams, then pull and stand up on the big foot ledge to reach some holds inside and along the edge of the crack. Get another good hold on the right edge, then reach the lip. Topout.
content.location: Backside of the Broken Boulder (opposite of Sustain and Refrain). Faces away from New Cross Dr.

content.description: This boulder is named after the crack that runs through its main face, which points to New Cross Dr. This face is vertical for 3.5 ft, before a roof that juts another 3 ft back. It then returns to a slab. The other side of this rock also looks fun, but has a gnarly landing and the topout's pretty vegetal. For the down climb, sit and slide down to the ledge on the SE corner, then sit and drop again to the rock. You may want to place an auxiliary pad under the down climb to make the drop to the ground more comfortable (since it's a rock), but it's not needed.
